SECRET.W.M. (4S16th kmqhjsionfFT UNDER LOCK AND key it is requested that special care may be taken toensure the secrecy of this document war CABINET 15 (43).miCONCLUSIONS of a Meeting of the War Cabinet held at 10 Downing Street,S.W. 1, on Monday, January 25, 1943, at 12 noon.The Right Hon. C. R. Attlee, M.P.; Deputy Prime Minister (m the Chair).The Right Hon. Anthony Eden, M.P.,Secretary of State for ForeignAffairs.The Right Hon. Ernest Bevin, M.P.,Minister of Labour and NationalService.The Right Hon. Sir John Anderson,M.P., Lord President of the Council.The Right Hon. Oliver Lyttelton,M.P., Minister of Production.The Right Hon. Herbert Morrison,M.P., Secretary of State for theHome Department and Minister ofHome Security.The following were also present:The Right Hon. Sir Kingsley Wood,M.P., Chancellor of the Exchequer.The Right Hon. Sir archibald sinclair, Bt., M.P., Secretary ofState for Air.The Hon. Sir Alexander Cadogan,Permanent Undter-Secretary of Statefor Foreign'Affairs.The Right Hon, Viscount Cranborne,Lord Privy Seal.The Right Hon. Sir Stafford Crd?ps,K.C., M.P., Minister of aircraft production.Lieut.-General A. E. Nye, Vice-Chiefof the Imperial General Staff.Sir Edward Bridges, Secretary.Contents.minute no. m Subject. page 1 Casablanca Conference .... ........x .... . .... 522 French North Africa ............ ............ 52General de Gaulle end General Giraud.[24976-^.23 Conclusions.)JLraca.General de gaulle andGeneral Giraud.(previous reference:W.M. (43) 12thConclusions,Minute 1.)a T^SF^ Stratagem 216 and 217, from Mr! MacmiHair^othe Foreign Secretary, were read to the War Cabinet. Theserecorded that a Joint Declaration, signed by General de Gaulle andGeneral Giraud,. would be issued at the same time as the communique of the Casablanca Conference. Each General wouldalsoissue a^Communique of his own. \ These would be issued inLondon and Algiers respectively. fThe War Cabinet-Took note of these telegrams, and decided that it would bedesirable that, pending publication of the Joint Declara-tion and the Communiques, an effort should be made to restrain public and Parliamentary comment in regard todmerences between French leaders.Offices of the War Cabinet, S. W. 1,January 29, 1943. HUSH-MOST SECRET IN
MESSAGE IN 2303/24/January
Date. 25.1.43.
Recd. 0355.
MOST IMMEDIATE.
257. STRATAGEM 2l6. Following for Foreign Secretary from MacMillan.
After arduous debates and considerable pressure the following positive results have been achieved.
(1) A joint declaration will be issued simultaneously with communique regarding conference here in terms of my immediately following telegram. This declaration is jointly issued by General de Gaulle and General Giraud.
(2) A photograph has been taken of the 2 Generals Air Cmdre. F. (/ corrupt group) and Admiral Q sitting together.
(3) A photograph has been taken of the 2 Generals shaking hands in presence of 2 Statesmen.
(4) Each general will issue a communique of his own in addition to joint declaration. These will be issued in London and Algiers respectively, simultaneously with the Generals' communique regarding the conference. The text of each communique is being shown to the other parties.
(5) Although the result may appear disappointing there is a general view that something has heen achieved and it might certainly have been worse. It will all depend on how the contacts which have been made can he followed up.
General Giraud feels satisfied and considers that nothing more could have been achieved at this first contact. I am arranging, with General Eisenhower's approval, for Mack to return home to-morrow, He will be able to give you a full report.
2303A/24
Repetition requested.
3 advance copies sent W.C.O.
Deputy Prime Minister
Foreign Secretary
Mr. Peak
Sir E. Bridges.
